Timothy Wall wrote:

> What constitutes the "framework"?  Just the Test interface (that would
> probably be the absolute minimum)?

I think it's mainly the way thinks are supposed to interact - the
skeleton, so to speak.

> I keep getting the impression here
> that anything anyone is unhappy with is "not really part of the
> framework, you should write your own if you don't like it", as opposed
> to a positive definition which states what is part of the framework,
> why, and why it needs to never be changed.

To me, it doesn't need to be changed because it's written in a way that
you easily can plug in your own implementations.

>   I hate hearing the implication "the code never changes so it must be
> really good code".

I don't remember someone saying that. What *I* said was that *perhaps*
the code "never" changes *because* it is really good code and therefore
doesn't need to be changed that much.

> The only thing that unchanging code implies is
> that no one has changed it. 

Unchanging code which is used much and with wich most people seem to be
quite happy might imply something more, though...

No hard feelings, Ilja
